Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation Research Project: Investigating the Impact of Peer Mentoring on STEM Retention and Persistence among Minority Undergraduate Women

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is a partnership among the University of the District of Columbia, Virginia State University, and the University of Memphis. It aims to pilot and investigate the effectiveness of a blended (face-to-face and virtual) STEM mentorship model that is designed to enhance career self-efficacy among minority female undergraduates and increase their STEM persistence. Secondarily, the project aims to enhance graduate students' mentoring skills and inspire their pursuit of STEM careers. Participants will participate in STEM communities to share ideas, receive encouragement, interact with STEM professionals, and receive mentoring from female graduate students. The project will focus on mitigating the underrepresentation of females in STEM by addressing the most documented problems that they face, persistence and self-efficacy, especially nontraditional female students. The researchers will produce evidence for a technology facilitated mentoring and career development model to broaden participation of underrepresented students in STEM graduate education and the workforce. At the same time, they will document an effective intervention to enhance the preparation of prospective STEM professionals.

The researchers propose to use a multiphase mixed-methods approach to address three research objectives: 1) Develop and examine the effectiveness of a STEM peer mentorship program on female undergraduate students' STEM career self-efficacy. 2) Develop and examine the effectiveness of a STEM peer mentoring program on graduate students' mentorship skills that will be transferrable to the workplace. and 3) Develop and examine the effectiveness of a STEM peer mentorship program on increasing undergraduate students' propensity to matriculate to graduate school and the STEM workforce. Data will be collected from interviews, surveys, and focus groups and analyzed using descriptive statistics. Research participants will include undergraduate and graduate students from each of the three partnering institutions. The research results are expected to have implications for broadening the participation of underrepresented minority females in STEM at other HBCUs and at other institutions while, at the same time, strengthening mentorship skills of graduate students planning to pursue STEM careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the project was to pilot and assess the effectiveness of a blended (i.e. face-to-face and virtual) STEM peer mentorship program to support the success and persistence of minority females in STEM degrees and to broaden participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM fields. A 6-week online training program was developed to prepare graduate students to mentor undergraduate students in STEM degree programs, with a specific focus on the experiences of women and underrepresented racial and ethnic minorities. The training was developed following Tinto’s (1975, 1987, 1993) Institutional Departure Model coupled with Bandura’s (2006) concept of self-efficacy (SE) and Lent, Brown, and Hackett’s (1994) Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT). Each module consisted of a topical discussion, case study, and personal application.

In Summer 2018, 7 graduate students enrolled at two historically black institutions (HBCUs) were selected to participate as mentors and completed the online training program. In Fall 2018, mentors were assigned 3-4 undergraduate students as mentees (23 mentees) and STEM Communities were established (mentoring relationships). Each Community was required to meet at least two times monthly face-to-face and an additional two times through a medium of their choice (e.g., online, phone). Mentors utilized the activities and skills learned in the online training to facilitate the STEM Communities through Spring 2019. Additionally, five STEM Luncheons were held across the two participating HBCUs which featured minority women in STEM as speakers. Participants were required to attend at least two STEM Luncheons.

Six research questions were explored:

RQ1: How has undergraduate students’ STEM career self-efficacy changed as a result of participation in the STEM peer mentorship program?

RQ2: Do undergraduate student participants believe the STEM peer mentorship program serves a useful purpose in furthering their STEM career self-efficacy? How?

RQ3: How has graduate students’ mentorship competencies changed as a result of participation in the STEM peer mentorship program?

RQ4: Do graduate student participants believe the STEM peer mentorship program serves to develop their mentorship abilities, which will give rise to furthering their success in the workforce? How?

RQ5: After participation in the STEM peer mentorship program, did undergraduate and graduate students report an intention to persist in their STEM program and in a STEM career?

RQ6: What STEM peer mentorship program factors were effective in supporting undergraduate and graduate students’ intent to continue to enroll in a STEM program through graduation and their intent to pursue a STEM career?

Three instruments and a series of persistence questions were used to assess self-efficacy, sense of community, career interest, and persistence: a researcher created STEM self-efficacy instrument, the modified Classroom Community Scale (Rovai, 2002), and the STEM Career Interest Survey (STEM-CIS; Kier, Blanchard, Osborne, & Albert, 2014).

Results demonstrated that (RQ1) mentees reported higher STEM achievement self-efficacy (M=111.76, SD=25.35) than a wait-list control group (M=96.50, SD=17.33); higher STEM career self-efficacy (M=109.81, SD=24.48) than a wait-list control group (M=94.00, SD=21.14); and (RQ2) increased STEM career self-efficacy from pre- (M= 93.86, SD= 24.52) to post-program (M=109.81, SD=24.48). Qualitative findings illuminated how participation in the program resulted in increased self-efficacy, interest, and intention to persist among mentees. (RQ3) Qualitative analysis also demonstrated that engagement in the program enhanced mentors’ views and growth in serving as a role model, ability to function as a mentor, ability to develop an other’s orientation, engagement in a STEM sisterhood, and development of mentoring competencies. (RQ4) Participation in the program increased mentors’ STEM self-efficacy, mentorship skills, and STEM career interest. Mentors experienced the greatest gains in STEM career interest in engineering, conceptualization of their personal mentoring model, STEM career self-efficacy, and STEM achievement self-efficacy. Prior to the program, only four mentors indicated their intent to persist in their degree and a STEM career. All six mentors indicated their degree and career persistence after the program. (RQ5) Post-program, all mentors reported intent to pursue a career in the areas in which they were obtaining a degree compared to 50% in the wait-list control group. All mentors reported intent to graduate from their STEM degree program compared to 66.7% in the wait-list control group. 95.2% of mentees reported intent to pursue a career in the areas in which they were obtaining a degree compared to 61.5% in the wait-list control group. 95.2% of mentees reported intent to graduate from their STEM degree program compared to 73.1% in the wait-list control group. (RQ6) Mentors reported training structure and content, community and connection, reflection, examples, online format, ability to serve as a role model and mentor, ability to develop an other’s orientation, engagement in a sisterhood, and development of mentoring competencies as effective in supporting STEM interest, self-efficacy, and intent to persist. Mentees reported conditions and opportunities for developing a sisterhood, experiences that motivated change, and positive STEM outcomes as effective in supporting STEM interest, self-efficacy, and intent to persist.
